Authors: Joseph W. Brown, Luke J. Harmon
Title: Archaeopteryx firmly perched in Avian tree
Keywords:
Archaeopteryx; Bayesian phylogenetic inference; Mkv model;
Avialae;
Abstract:
Archaeopteryx is a pivotal fossil taxon that underlies
nearly all hypotheses regarding the trajectory of early avian evolution.
Xu et al. argue that an analysis of character state data from the newly
described Late Jurassic theropod taxon Xiaotingia zhengi changes the
phylogenetic and taxonomic position of Archaeopteryx, moving it from its
traditional position in Avialae (birds and their close relatives) and
into Deinonychosauria (troodontids and dromaeosaurs). This move
challenges Archaeopteryxs famed standing as ‘the first bird.’ While this
provocative hypothesis has the potential to rewrite our understanding of
early avian evolution, we find no support for the hypothesis as
presented. We reanalysed these data using explicit model-based
phylogenetic reconstruction methods, rejecting Xu et al.s hypothesis and
providing strong statistical support for the traditional position of
Archaeopteryx at the base of Avialae.
